thread.title: Trump on Putin being a 'killer': 'What do you think — our country's so innocent?' | Washington Examiner
thread.title_full: Trump on Putin being a 'killer': 'What do you think — our country's so innocent?' | Washington Examiner

author: Daniel Chaitin
title: Trump on Putin being a 'killer': 'What do you think — our country's so innocent?' | Washington Examiner
text:
President Trump questioned the innocence of the U.S. because it has "a lot of killers," during an exchange about working with Russia to defeat terrorism abroad.
During a clip of a interview with Fox News' Bill O'Reilly, set to air Sunday before the Super Bowl, Trump was questioned on whether he respects Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"I do respect him but —," Trump started to say.
"Do you? Why?", O'Reilly interrupted.
Subscribe today to get intelligence and analysis on defense and national security issues in your Inbox each weekday morning from veteran journalists Jamie McIntyre and Jacqueline Klimas.
Sorry, there was a problem processing your email signup. Please try again later. Processing... Thank you for signing up for the Daily on Defense newsletter. You should receive your first issue soon! "Well, I respect a lot of people but that doesn't mean I'm going to get along with him," Trump answered. "He's a leader of his country. I say it's better to get along with Russia than not. And if Russia helps us in the fight against ISIS, which is a major fight, and Islamic terrorism all over the world — that's a good thing."
He added: "Will I get along with him? I have no idea."
O'Reilly shot back: "But he's a killer though. Putin's a killer."
"There are a lot of killers. We've got a lot of killers," Trump replied. "What do you think — our country's so innocent?"
The clip did not reveal whether Trump went on to explain who the killers are or what he meant by questioning the country's innocence.
Also from the Washington Examiner Justice Department appeals judge's order to block Trump's travel ban 
The U.S. Justice Department is appealing a federal judge's order for a temporary nationwide restraining order on President Trump's travel ban.
About 24 hours after U.S. District Judge James Robart ruled Friday in favor of a lawsuit by Washington state and Minnesota, taking action against the week-old executive action, the Trump administration is making good on a threat to push back.
Earlier in the day Saturday, the Homeland Security Department announced it "has suspended any and all actions implementing the affected sections of the Executive Order," in accordance with the judge's ruling. DHS also confirmed that the Justice Department would file an emergency stay of Robart's order, a move acting DHS press secretary Gillian
By Daniel Chaitin • 02/04/17 7:27 PM Top Story Justice Department appeals judge's order to block Trump's travel ban 
The U.S. Justice Department is appealing a federal judge's order for a temporary nationwide restraining order on President Trump's travel ban, according to multiple reports early Saturday evening.
About 24 hours after U.S. District Judge James Robart ruled Friday in favor of a lawsuit by Washington state and Minnesota, taking action against the week-old executive action, Reuters and the Associated Press reported that the Trump administration is making good on a threat to push back.
BREAKING: U.S.
